original_data.question:
Two weeks after undergoing an emergency cardiac catherization with stenting for unstable angina pectoris, a 61-year-old man has decreased urinary output and malaise. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and osteoarthritis of the hips. Prior to admission, his medications were insulin and naproxen. He was also started on aspirin, clopidogrel, and metoprolol after the coronary intervention. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 93/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. Examination shows mottled, reticulated purplish discoloration of the feet. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin count 14 g/dL
Leukocyte count 16,400/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 56%
Eosinophils 11%
Lymphocytes 31%
Monocytes 2%
Platelet count 260,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 68 mm/h
Serum
Urea nitrogen 25 mg/dL
Creatinine 4.2 mg/dL
Renal biopsy shows intravascular spindle-shaped vacuoles. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?"
original_data.augmented_question:
Two weeks after undergoing an emergency coronary intervention with stenting for unstable myocardial ischemia, a 61-year-old man has decreased urination output and general feeling of illness. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and degenerative joint disease of the hips. Prior to admission, his medications were insulin and ibuprofen. He was also started on aspirin, clopidogrel, and beta blockers after the cardiac procedure. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 93/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. Examination shows mottled, reticulated purplish discoloration of the feet. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin count 14 g/dL
Leukocyte count 16,400/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 56%
Eosinophils 11%
Lymphocytes 31%
Monocytes 2%
Platelet count 260,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 68 mm/h
Serum
Urea nitrogen 25 mg/dL
Creatinine 4.2 mg/dL
Renal biopsy shows intravascular spindle-shaped vacuoles. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?"

I replaced medical terms with synonyms as follows:

- Cardiac catherization -> Coronary intervention
- Unstable angina pectoris -> Myocardial ischemia
- Type 2 diabetes mellitus -> Diabetes mellitus (no change needed, but could be rephrased to "type 2 diabetes" for more specificity)
- Osteoarthritis of the hips -> Degenerative joint disease
- Insulin and naproxen -> Insulin and ibuprofen
- Aspirin, clopidogrel, and metoprolol -> Aspirin, clopidogrel, and beta blockers
- Low-grade fever (38°C) is not changed but could be rephrased to "low-grade pyrexia"
- Urinary output -> Urination output
- Malaise -> General feeling of illness

model_response:
Renal papillary necrosis is a well-known complication of sickle cell disease, diabetes mellitus, and analgesic abuse. The vasoocclusive crisis in sickle cell disease is caused by the blockage of the small vessels by the rigid, sickled cells. The sluggish blood flow in the necrotic areas may lead to bacterial infection, which can further aggravate the symptoms. The other choices are not related to sickle cell disease.

###Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>
